revision.text:
'''Bonny Warner''' (now '''Bonny Simi''', born April 7, 1962 in [[Mount Baldy, California]]<ref>[http://www.brainyhistory.com/events/1962/april_7_1962_125213.html Brainyhistory.com profile] - accessed October 25, 2007</ref>) is an [[United States|American]] [[luge]]r who competed from the early 1980s to the early 1990s.<ref name=alp2001>[http://cf.alpa.org/internet/alp/2001/oct01p24.htm Air Line Pilots Association profile on Warner's bid for the 2002 Winter Olympics in Salt Lake City] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071215154844/http://cf.alpa.org/internet/alp/2001/oct01p24.htm |date=December 15, 2007 }} - accessed October 25, 2007</ref> She later competed in women's [[bobsleigh]] from 1999 to 2002.<ref name=alp2001 /> She was a pilot for [[United Airlines]]<ref name=alp2001 /> from 1990 to 2004, when she quit United and went to work for [[JetBlue]] Airways.
==Luge career== Warner's career in [[luge]] began when she was a torchbearer for the [[1980 Winter Olympics]] in [[Lake Placid, New York]] while as a freshman from [[Stanford University]].<ref name=alp2001 /> While watching the [[Luge at the 1980 Winter Olympics|luge competitions in Lake Placid]], she became hooked on the event.<ref name=alp2001 /> This would lead Warner to travel to [[West Germany]] and follow luge activities over there.<ref name=alp2001 /> Warner would then learn to speak fluent [[German language|German]] while over there.<ref name=alp2001 /> While at Stanford, Warner switched her major from [[civil engineering]] to [[broadcast journalism]] after earning an [[athletic scholarship]] to play [[field hockey]]. Competing in three [[Winter Olympics]], she earned her best finish of sixth in the women's singles event at [[Calgary]] in [[1988 Winter Olympics|1988]].<ref name=1988w>[http://www.todor66.com/olim/1984w/Luge_Women_Singles.html 1984 luge women's singles results]</ref> Warner also organized Luge camps throughout the United States, which made a huge contribution to the growth of the sport in this country.
==Broadcasting career== Following the [[1992 Winter Olympics]], Warner retired and served as a [[color commentator]] for [[CBS Sports]] during their coverage of the [[Winter Olympics]] in [[1994 Winter Olympics|1994]] and [[1998 Winter Olympics|1998]].<ref name=alp2001 /> Prior to that, she had been a [[television]] sports reporter for the [[San Francisco]] area during the mid-1980s.<ref name=alp2001 />
==Airline career== After the [[1988 Winter Olympics]] in Calgary, Warner earned a 10,000 [[United States dollar|USD]] scholarship and earned her [[aviator]]'s license.<ref name=alp2001 /> Prior to joining United in November 1990, she worked as a flight instructor and a corporate pilot.<ref name=alp2001 /> One of Warner's clients as a corporate pilot was [[Bill Graham (promoter)|the late promoter Bill Graham]].<ref name=alp2001 />
==Personal life== Warner married Tony Simi, a [[firefighter]] and [[paramedic]] who was in one of her classes in 1996.<ref name=alp2001 /> A daughter, Katlin, was born in 1998.<ref name=alp2001 />
==Bobsleigh career== After a 1999 vacation to [[Park City, Utah]], Warner went over to bobsleigh and competed from 1999 to 2002.<ref name=alp2001 /> While searching for a brakeman, she discovered [[Vonetta Flowers]], who would go on to win the gold medal in the two-woman event at the [[2002 Winter Olympics]] in [[Salt Lake City]].<ref name=alp2001 /><ref>[http://daily.stanford.edu/article/1999/5/18/stanfordTargetedForUnusuallyExceptionalAthletesInAnUnusualSport May 18, 1999 issue of ''The Stanford Daily'' featuring Warner and her bobsleigh pursuits]{{dead link|date=November 2016 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} - Accessed October 25, 2007.</ref> Warner's best seasonal finish in the [[List of Bobsleigh World Cup champions|Bobsleigh World Cup]] was third overall in 2000-1.<ref>[http://sports123.com/bob/wwc-2.html List of two-woman bobsleigh World Cup champions since 1995] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20111105081037/http://sports123.com/bob/wwc-2.html |date=November 5, 2011 }}</ref> During the 2001-2 Bobsleigh World Cup, Warner carried on her sled a memorial to the victims of the [[September 11, 2001 attacks]] in [[New York City|New York]] and [[Washington, DC]].<ref name=alp2001 /> She tried out for the 2002 US team, but did not qualify though Flowers did.<ref name=alp2001 /> She also participated in simulation for bobsleigh starts prior to the 2002 games.<ref>[http://www.asmenews.org/archives/backissues/mar02/features/bobsled.html American Society of Mechanical Engineers story on Warner's participation on a bobsleigh simulator prior to the 2002 Winter Olympics] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070407004608/http://www.asmenews.org/archives/backissues/mar02/features/bobsled.html |date=April 7, 2007 }} - accessed October 25, 2007</ref> Because she did not qualify for the 2002 Winter Olympics, she worked for [[NBC Sports]] during their television coverage of the games.
==Life since the Winter Olympics== Since her retirement from bobsleigh, Warner was a pilot for JetBlue Airways and now works in management for the company.<ref>[http://www.speaking.com/speakers/bonnywarner.html Speakers Platform featuring Warner] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071225022919/http://www.speaking.com/speakers/bonnywarner.html |date=December 25, 2007 }} - access October 25, 2007.</ref>
